English: "Nautilus to O. Got {un}another{/un} species to send your way. Hope you're getting all the data we've been sending you. Our lab is {un}totally wrecked{/un}
column4: but you've got the {un}AquaLab{/un}. Maybe you can figure out if this thing has a weakness. If there's some way we can get out of here alive."

O. I don't know why I keep sending these. I guess it's just nice to pretend you're {un}listening{/un}. I really wished you could've come on this mission with me. But now I'm glad you didn't. For the record
column5: I'm {un}sorry{/un} about the whole crashed sub thing. I {un}shouldn't have{/un} pressured you to take the sub out at night. If you get this message

column6: because I don't know how much longer we can hold on. There are {un}cracks{/un} in the outer glass. Our oxygen is dwindling. {un}Almost{/un} out of time."

English: "Nautilus to O. This is it. {un}The last{/un} of our data. Maybe it'll be enough to {un}find a way out{/un} of this mess. We've got a few days of oxygen left. Or {un}maybe just a few{/un} seconds

English: "Antigua plataforma de excavación petrolífera abandonada por la empresa. Ahora es el hogar de un arrecife tan discutido por un grupo de científicos investigadores."

"Un hábitat de camarones económicamente valioso. Las aguas apenas profundas deberían ser perfectas para el placer de los camarones. Los informes locales sobre el cambio de las condiciones son preocupantes."

We want to be able to create a stress-free environment where all kinds of kelp can thrive and reproduce."

"The rig should be removed from the reef."
"The rig should be left to remain in the reef."
"Head back out to {h}Site O{/h} and scan around to find the elusive jellyfish."

"We want to see what might happen in the future for the turtles

English: "The turtle population will begin to decrease"
"Why is no one talking about the lionfish? There's a reason they prefer the reef ecosystem.  They must be interacting with the coral. What do they do?!"
"Lionfish are predators that eat other fish"
"Fisher interest in hunting {nameof Lionfish} is growing. We need to model how hunting might work so we can decide whether to regulate or even advocate for it."
"Scan the historical populations and water chemistry data of {h}Site S{/h}"
"Obtain all rules regarding what eats what at {h}Site S{/h}"
"Obtain all stress rules for organisms at {h}Site S{/h}"

"Present an organism that stresses the coral and how it stresses the coral"
"Present a chain of facts that explain how Lionfish influence coral populations"
"We're trying to determine why this reef has been struggling
column4: so we installed artificial reefs in an effort to fix it. Report back on the reef's status."

English: "Count current coral and artificial reef populations"
"Report to the {nameof RS-Coral} about whether the fake reef helped the coral population"
"The artificial reef has not helped coral populations"

"Another researcher reported that the coral is covered in turf algae. Those lionfish scare me
column4: so I avoid that area as much as possible. Can you double check and see if you can figure out why there is so much algae?"

English: "Measure the rate at which {nameof BlueTang} eats {nameof TurfAlgae}"
"{map-name}Model{/map-name} Blue Tang and Turf Algae populations."
"Report on why there is so much {nameof TurfAlgae}"
"There are not enough fish to balance the Turf Algae population"
"The Lionfish are making the Turf Algae reproduce faster"

column4: are the Mussels at {h}Site C{/h} being adversely affected? We're particularly interested in how their reproduction rate has changed. The local restaurants want to keep serving mussels!"

English: "Measure Mussel reproduction rates when not stressed"

"Measure the rate at which Bull Kelp consume light"
"Some researchers down south counted the pod on arrival and one is missing. They think she got lost up here

"Find out what happened to the whale. I'll give you some info on whales and a microscope if you accept this."
"Search the ice for signs of microscopic life"
"How long ago did the missing whale die? We can use the decomposition model to determine her time of death."
"Scan and Count all organisms at {h}Site W{/h}"
"Search {h}Site W{/h} to find the missing whale tracker"

"Scan all organisms feasting on the whale fall in {h}Site W{/h}"
"Count the amount of detritus found on the whale carcass"
"Present your visual model of the species interactions at {h}Site W{/h}"
"What killed her? We have two hypotheses. It was either something about the water
column4: or lack of a food source
column5: since whales have no natural predators."

"What sorts of creatures live beneath the ice?"
"We didn't think an ecosystem would be able to survive with such a low amount of light under the ice. Yet

"We're seeing a lot of Glass Sponges at {h}Site X{/h}

English: "Nereocystis luetkeana\n\nThese plant-like growths are actually composed of protists
"Macrocystis pyrifera\n\nThe biggest and best of the kelp! Make wonderful cookies
"Thalassoma bifasciatum\n\nLarger predators will allow these ""cleaner fish"" to eat algae and parasites off their skin without any ha-wrasse-ment."
"Copepoda\n\nSuper swimmers who can travel 295 ft/hr. Good thing they can't participate in the olympics."
"Calanus Glacialus\n\nHow would you cope with being a tiny arctic crustacean?"
"Caretta caretta\n\nThese ""pearls"" are actually made of algae
column4: but they're still treasures to me."

English: "Caretta caretta\n\nThese vulnerable sea turtles have probably never even seen a log."
"Aurelia aurita\n\nOpportunistic critters can wait 25 years in their polyp stage before maturing. Also thrive in waters otherwise uninhabitable. Make a tasty chip."
"Strombus gigas\n\nListen to the ocean in their shells. Well
column4: after they move out of course."

English: "Epinephelus morio\n\nThese fish clear detritus from around their dens
column4: opening space for other critters - truly the janitors of the sea!"

English: "Acropora cervicornis\n\nThis coral formation has millions of tiny polyps and symbiotic zooxanthelle... but no antlers."
"Thalassia testudinum\n\nTurtles must really like this stuff."
"Paracanthurus hepatus\n\nThe great lawn mowers of the coral reef. Unpaid that is."

English: "Pterois volitans\n\nThis creature actually does have quite a beautiful mane... but it's made of deadly spines."

"Astarte Borealis\n\nThis bivalve has teeth! Three to be precise."
"Balaena mysticetus\n\nUnusually thick skulls bash through ice to let them breathe
column4: missing dorsal fins mean they don't catch it on the ice. Priorities."

English: "Riftia pachyptila\n\nThese alien-looking worms get much of their biomass from symbiotic sulfur-eating bacteria."
"Oncorhynchus tshawytscha\n\nThese salmon change color when they return to freshwater to mate - It's basically their prom."
"Bacillariophyceae\n\nThese silica-shelled algae are responsible for over 20% of Earth's oxygen
column4: and much of its kitty litter."

English: "Myxini\n\nThese eel-shaped fish release copious amounts of slime and can tie themselves in knots. ""Hag"" sounds about right."
"Reniera Rufescens\n\nSea sponges may look like weird plants
column4: but they're actually some of the first animals to evolve."

English: "Aperusa Glacialus\n\nThese flea-like amphipods spend most of their life clinging to the bottom of sea ice
"Clione Limacina\n\nSometimes known as the common clione
column4: these little beauties are also known as naked sea butterflies or sea angels."

English: "CH4\n\nEnergy rich compound. Most commonly associated with cow farts."
"Bathyraja abyssicola\n\nThese rays' mission: to boldly go where no sun has gone before."

column4: these bacteria breathe in hydrogen gas and exhale methane. Talk about bad breath."

English: "Bathypolypus arcticus\n\nAlso known as the spoonarm octopus. Maybe they have a fondness for cereal."
"Chrysaora Melanaster\n\nStinging and irritating - just like land nettle."
"Histriophoca fasciata\n\nTheir buoyancy sacs may be unique among seals
"Lamna ditropis\n\nDon't let their name fool you: they're not a type of salmon
column4: but one of their most voracious predators!"

English: "Bathyphellia margaritacea\n\nTop of the food chain at the top of the world. Mainly because the North Pole isn't the most hospitable ecosystem."
"Chionoecetes opilio\n\nMolting season turns these hard-shelled crabs into squishy blobs until they harden again. It's all about growth."

column4: but they do bore into bones to eat the marrow."

English: "Microscopic recyclers. Does this count as eating?"
"That's just dead organic matter. Analysis says it's 78% icky."
"Acropora palmata\n\nThey are similar to their Staghorn cousins
column4: but these coral grows in horizontal shelves."

English: "These tiny photosynthesizers are responsible for your oxygen. Remember to thank them."
"Microscopic parasite that lives on the Tang."
"Diodogorgia Nodulifera\n\nThese sea fans extend feathery tentacles to capture plankton. Maybe they could also be used to cool yourself?"

"Bathymodiolus brooksi\n\nThese deep-sea mussels have endosymbiotic methanogens. They must be desperate to team up with someone so stinky."
